abstract.para: On Linux, certain commands require elevated privileges. Learn how a regular user can run any command as &rootuser; by prefacing the command with &sudo;.

topic.para: The execution of certain commands requires &rootuser; privileges. For security reasons, it is not recommended to log in as &rootuser;. A safer approach is to log in as a regular user and run the command prefaced with &sudo; to gain &rootuser; privileges.

As a regular user, you can run any command as &rootuser; by prefacing the command with &sudo;. After successful authentication with the &rootuser; password, the command is executed with elevated privileges. The elevated privileges persist for a certain period of time, so you do not need to provide the &rootuser; password again when running another &sudo;.
